As for your second question, dust clouds are spread all over. Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
When we talk about 'dust', we are actually referring to any sort of matter that isn't located inside of a star. This dust can be made up of Hydrogen, Helium, or even heavier elements like Oxygen and Carbon that were expelled by an exploding star. It would be more correct to think of the dust as being in clouds instead of sheets. You will find dust all around the universe, and it is one of our main obstacles to taking accurate measures. As for your second question, dust clouds are spread all over. Dust can be behind or beside the object, but as that doesn't effect our measurements as much as a cloud in front of the object, we tend to not care about those (except for in cases like in the video). Input.posts:
I've watched the first two videos from week 3 so far. I cannot help but notice though that loading up the same observation as is the video #2 into DS9 yields slightly different results, that is -- (1) DS9 loads no default regions, (2) the scale is somewhat different. Neither is crucial to analysis -- all of us should be able to replicate those regions if we need to, or set the scale more to our liking, but I wonder where the difference is coming from. Either the observation file has been changed since recording of the video, or this has to do with the fact most installations of DS9 I have around are in fact older (v. 6.1.2). ;-) Anyway, it would be interesting to see which one is more likely. Does anyone experience the same issue? Cheers, T.
Upvotes:
1
Hmm. This is even more fascinating than I suggested -- on another machine with exactly the same config (system, DS9 version, settings) it loaded just fine. So I wasn't able to replicate the issue. But here's another clue: the difference was that on the second box it correctly loaded ngkper.fits, whereas on the first one, the name of the file being downloaded through DS9 is 3454.fits. :-) I love such situations. :-) T.

Even though the title bar showed clearly I was seeing the MOOC version of the observation, the url loaded was from Chandra-Ed! Problem solved, then, if it makes any difference to you. :-) Cheers, T.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Good question! I'm glad you spent some time thinking about this. Let's find out where this factor of 1/2 comes from in $$\Delta f$$ . If the light source emits light with a frequency $$f$$, then $$f_1$$ is the frequency observed when it is moving toward us, and $$f_2$$ is the frequency observed as it is moving away from us. Because it will be moving toward us at the same speed it will be moving away from us, both $$f_1$$ and $$f_2$$ will be shifted by the same amount. $$f_1$$ will be blueshifted because it is moving toward us, and $$f_2$$ will be redshifted because it is moving away from us. So.... $$f_1$$ = $$f$$ + $$\Delta f$$ and $$f_2$$ = $$f$$ - $$\Delta f$$ If we take the difference of these two frequencies... $$f_1$$ - $$f_2$$=($$f$$ + $$\Delta f$$) - ($$f$$ - $$\Delta f$$) = 2$$\Delta f$$ $$\Rightarrow$$ $$\Delta f$$ = $$\frac{f_1 - f_2}{2}$$ Hopefully that helps some!
